unnormalised: The air in May always felt different. Thicker, heavier, pregnant with the promise of monsoons that never seemed to arrive quickly enough. But this May was different for a different reason. For me, at least. It was the month of my ICSE board exams.
normalised: The air in May always felt different. Thicker, heavier, pregnant with the promise of monsoons that never seemed to arrive quickly enough. But this May was different for a different reason. For me, at least. It was the month of my I-C-S-E board exams.

unnormalised: I remember the day the results came out. 25/05/2008. My palms were sweaty, the kind of sweaty that left damp patches on my already worn copy of "Merchant of Venice." My friends, Rohan and Aisha, were no better. We’d all crammed together, fueled by endless cups of chai and the anxiety that only 10th standard exams could induce.
normalised: I remember the day the results came out. twenty fifth May two thousand and eight. My palms were sweaty, the kind of sweaty that left damp patches on my already worn copy of "Merchant of Venice." My friends, Rohan and Aisha, were no better. We’d all crammed together, fueled by endless cups of chai and the anxiety that only tenth standard exams could induce.

unnormalised: Rohan, ever the optimist, kept saying, “Arre, bhai, chill maar! What’s the worst that can happen? We’ll just study again next year.” Aisha, practical as always, had already started researching tuition classes in case she didn’t get the required 85% to get into the science stream. Me? I was just trying not to throw up.
normalised: Rohan, ever the optimist, kept saying, “Arre, bhai, chill maar! What’s the worst that can happen? We’ll just study again next year.” Aisha, practical as always, had already started researching tuition classes in case she didn’t get the required eighty five percent to get into the science stream. Me? I was just trying not to throw up.

unnormalised: We finally logged onto the website. The internet was slow, typical of BSNL broadband back then. Each second felt like an eternity. Finally, the page loaded. My roll no: 1234567. Name: Priya Sharma.
normalised: We finally logged onto the website. The internet was slow, typical of B-S-N-L broadband back then. Each second felt like an eternity. Finally, the page loaded. My roll number: one two three four five six seven. Name: Priya Sharma.

unnormalised: And then, the numbers swam before my eyes. English: 88. Hindi: 92. Maths: 96. Science: 94. Social Studies: 90. Overall: 92%. I’d done it. We'd all done it. The collective sigh of relief could have been heard across the entire colony. Aisha got her 86%, Rohan scraped by with 70%, but he passed.
normalised: And then, the numbers swam before my eyes. English: eighty eight. Hindi: ninety two. Maths: ninety six. Science: ninety four. Social Studies: ninety. Overall: ninety two percent. I’d done it. We'd all done it. The collective sigh of relief could have been heard across the entire colony. Aisha got her eighty six percent, Rohan scraped by with seventy percent, but he passed.

unnormalised: The celebrations that followed were epic. Mom made my favourite, gulab jamun. Dad bought me the Harry Potter book I had been eyeing for months. And we all went out for dinner at the local Udipi restaurant. Dosas, idlis, uttapam – we devoured it all, celebrating not just our scores, but the end of an era. The era of textbooks, late-night study sessions, and the constant fear of failure.

unnormalised: Looking back, those ICSE exams weren’t just about marks. They were about friendship, resilience, and the first taste of true accomplishment. They were a rite of passage, a memory etched in time. The scores have faded into insignificance compared to the lessons learned and the bonds forged. And every time May rolls around, I am reminded of the girl who faced her biggest fear, armed with nothing but a worn copy of Shakespeare and the unwavering support of her friends.
